learning_outcomes.description: Identify and explain key national security laws and approaches.
Identify and explain relevant human rights and constitutional principles and the mechanisms by which they are protected.
Identify and discuss key legal and political processes, actors and challenges in the field of national security law.
Conduct and communicate research in national security law, applying appropriate research principle and methods.
Investigate and critically analyse complex information, problems and concepts in relation to national security.
Independently critique and evaluate the justifications, effectiveness and impacts of national security law from a principled perspective.

assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Your weekly Workshop Guide will include an exercise. These exercises are designed to guide your reading and to prepare you for what we are going to do in class. So, it is recommended that you complete the exercise every week. Five of those exercises will be assessed. It is up to you to keep track of how many you have handed in for assessment and to double-check with the course coordinator that you have had 5 assessed by the end of semester.

There are 10 Workshops over the course of the Semester, so you will have 10 opportunities to hand-in your answers. You only need to hand in 5 of these weekly exercises, each of which will be graded out of 2 (adding up to a total of 10 marks by the end of the Semester). Those 2 marks will be awarded on the basis of the following Marking Criteria:

  • A complete response to the assigned task, adhering to all instructions.
  • Evidence of independent and genuine engagement with the task including appropriate pre-reading and research.
  • Clear and competent written communication skills.

This assessment item will only be accepted in-class and in-person, and cannot be handed in by someone else. Please remember to write your name and student number on your hand-in (writing your name on it makes it easier to hand back in class the following week).

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
An In-Semester Exam will be held after 6pm on 9 September 2025. The exam will be open book (any written or printed material is permitted in the exam; it may also be annotated) and will examine material covered in Weeks 1 to 5 of the course.

More detailed information will be provided on Blackboard and in Lectures and Workshops during Semester.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
The primary piece of assessment for this course is a Research Essay of maximum 2,800 words excluding footnote references engaging in independent critical analysis in the field of terrorism law and human rights. You will have the opportunity to select a topic for your Research Essay from a list provided during the mid-semester break. That list and further information and instructions will appear on Blackboard.

The grade for the Research Essay will be based upon the following Marking Criteria:

  • Knowledge and Understanding: Demonstrated comprehension, knowledge and understanding of the research topic, including clear identification and explanation of laws, rights and principles as relevant to the research question.
  • Research and Referencing: Evidence of independent research and use of materials, supported by comprehensive referencing (in accordance with the Australian Guide to Legal Citation).
  • Critical Analysis: Evidence of substantial independent critical thinking, originality and insight in relation to the research question. Analysis should be balanced and engage with counterarguments.
  • Reasoned Conclusion: Clear and persuasive conclusions in response to the research question.
  • Writing Skills: Clear communication of information and ideas including a logical structure and scholarly written expression.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assignment must be submitted electronically via the assessment submission link on the course Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site.
